description: Description: Ocean Networks Canada operates the world-leading cabled ocean observatories for the advancement of science and the benefit of Canada. These observatories collect data on physical, chemical, biological, and geological aspects of the ocean over long time periods, supporting research on complex Earth processes in ways not previously possible.

els.description: Description: The Arctic region includes a shore station, community-based observatory in Cambridge Bay, and observations harvested from instruments in additional locations across the north.
Description: Near-shore mini-observatory to study the interaction of sea-ice, water, weather and biology the in Arctic.
In September 2014, divers used cameras to obtain visual transects of the seafloor at Cambridge Bay.
els.name: Diver Data

els.description: Description: A drifting buoy deployed in Cambridge Bay provides temperature measurements through the air-ice-water interface using satellite communication.
els.name: Safe Passage Buoy

Cambridge Bay

els.description: Description: Darnley Bay is a large inlet off the southern side of Amundsen Gulf. The bay is approximately 45 km long and 32 km wide at its mouth. Two drainage areas in Darnley Bay include the Hornaday and Brock Rivers. The coastline of Darnley Bay includes many sandy and gravel beaches.
els.name: Darnley Bay

els.description: Description: Davis Strait is a waterway between Baffin Island and Greenland.
els.name: Davis Strait

els.description: Description: Dease Strait is an east-west waterway between the Kent Peninsula on the mainland and Victoria Island in Nunavut Territory. The eastern end is approximately 19 kilometers wide at Cambridge Bay.
Description: Drifting buoys in the Arctic provide meteorological and oceanographic data in real-time via satellite communication.
els.name: Oceanetic Buoy 1

els.description: Description: Drifting buoys in the Arctic provide meteorological and oceanographic data in real-time via satellite communication.
els.name: Oceanetic Buoy 2
Dease Strait

els.description: Description: Franklin Strait is located between southeastern Prince of Wales Island and the Boothia Peninsula.
els.name: Franklin Strait

els.description: Description: Peel Sound is located in Nunavut and separates Somerset Island on the east from Prince of Wales Island on the west. Parry Channel is located to the north end of Peel Sound, and its southern end merges with Franklin Strait. Several islands located in Peel Sound include Lock, Vivian, Prescott, Pandora, Otrick, Barth, De la Roquette, and Gibson.
Description: Drifting buoys in the Arctic provide meteorological and oceanographic data in real-time via satellite communication.
els.name: Oceanetic Buoy 1

els.description: Description: Drifting buoys in the Arctic provide meteorological and oceanographic data in real-time via satellite communication.
els.name: Oceanetic Buoy 2
Peel Sound

els.description: Description: Queen Maud Gulf is located between the northern coast of Nunavut territory mainland and the southeastern coast of Victoria Island. At the western end of the gulf is Cambridge Bay and Dease Strait.
Description:Jenny Lind Island is a small island in the Kitikmeot Region of Nunavut, Canada. The island is located in the Queen Maud Gulf, about 120 km southeast of Cambridge Bay.
els.name: Jenny Lind Island
Queen Maud Gulf

els.description: Description: Victoria Strait is a waterway between Victoria Island and King William Island in Nunavut Territory. The strait is approximately 160 km long.
els.name: Victoria Strait
Arctic

els.description: Description: The Atlantic region observations are from the Fundy Ocean Research Center for Energy in the Bay of Fundy.

Description: The Bay of Fundy is located between the provinces of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia. Vertical tidal range has been measured to reach over 16 metres.Tidal currents are fast, reaching over 5.1 metres/second at peak surface speed. On a flood tide, 160 billion tons of seawater flow into the Bay of Fundy.
Description: Near-shore mini-observatory to monitor meteorological conditions, water properties and waves at Minas Passage.

els.description: Description: Sensors and weather stations are installed on ferry vessels in the Salish Sea. Data is collected from routes between Vancouver Island and the mainland of British Columbia. Data is transmitted to Ocean Networks Canada shore stations via a WIFI connection.
Description: Ferry Route that travels between Horseshoe Bay terminal in West Vancouver, BC and the Departure Bay terminal, Nanaimo BC.
els.name: Horseshoe Bay - Departure Bay

els.description: Description: Ferry Route that travels between Tsawwassen terminal in Vancouver, BC and the Duke Point terminal, Nanaimo BC.

els.description: Description: The Northeast Pacific Ocean includes marine and coastal waters along the west coast of North America. The NEPTUNE observatory is located in this region.

For research information, contact Fabio de Leo, Staff Scientist,
or Richard Dewey, Associate Director, Science Services
 
Related: Planning for Barkley’s future

els.description: Description: The Salish Sea includes a network of channels and coastal waters near Vancouver Island. The Salish Sea includes the Strait of Georgia, Strait of Juan de Fuca, Saanich Inlet and Puget Sound. The VENUS and Mill Bay observatories are located in the Salish Sea.

els.description: Project of the Pacific Salmon Foundation.
Baynes Sound is the channel between Denman Island and Vancouver Island. Data are collected from this area as a part of the Salish Sea Marine Survival Project.

A patrol is a person or team that conducts CTD casts and/or sampling in the field. A patrol is identified by a unique set of devices used in the field (including CTD, oxygen sensor, fluorometer, and mobile Android device).
els.name: Patrol 4
Baynes Sound
